update.description:
‌

* this fixes the collada loader so models from mixamo.com can be loaded correctly. It should also fix issue #2582.

    List of changes:



    * `boost::split(words, line, boost::is_any_of(" "))` in `BVHLoader.cc` and `ColladaLoader.cc` looks like a bug as a result of tab being replaced with spaces, replaced with `boost::split(words, line, boost::is_any_of(" \t"));`
    * Scale the skeleton according to the collada's meter parameter
    * Import the whole scene in a Collada file as an actor, because animations may target the scene outside the skeleton, this is required so some animations work correctly
    * Allow `Skeleton` to store data of raw node weights with multiple vertices group. The raw node weights are overwritten when loading a new submesh, while not strictly required becauses submeshes are load sequentially, it is probably more "correct" to have the full node weights available.
    * Map the animation to the target bone's name as opposed to the id \(target bone is still chosen by the id\). Since the skeleton nodes are identified by its name in the rendering process, mapping the animations to id may result in missing animations.
    * Fix loading `<transparency>` tag, gazebo uses 0 opaque, collada uses 1 opaque. Note that is is separate from the `<transparent>` tag where the color is defined in the `opaque` attribute.
    * Separate the positions and normals from the texture mapping buffers. When doing software skinning OGRE requires the positions and normal to be in their own buffers, see `https://ogrecave.github.io/ogre/api/1.11/_animation.html` under `Vertex buffer arrangements`.
    
* remove unused includes
update.title: Gazebo9 collada mixamo fix

content.html: I've confirmed that the new test fails without the fixes in this PR and that CI looks clean. I'm not familiar with the Collada or Skeleton code, so I didn't review that in depth, but I'm happy with the CI status.

* this fixes the collada loader so models from mixamo.com can be loaded correctly. It should also fix issue #2582.

    List of changes:



    * `boost::split(words, line, boost::is_any_of(" "))` in `BVHLoader.cc` and `ColladaLoader.cc` looks like a bug as a result of tab being replaced with spaces, replaced with `boost::split(words, line, boost::is_any_of(" \t"));`

content.raw:
Thanks for the input! Yeah, the ABI change should not be necessary, all the function signature changes are to accommodate the protected data member too. I did not think of the ABI impact when I changed it, it would probably be best to revert it.

What would be a good test to do? Should I try loading a dae from mixamo and check if the mesh is imported correctly?
content.html:
Thanks for the input! Yeah, the ABI change should not be necessary, all the function signature changes are to accommodate the protected data member too. I did not think of the ABI impact when I changed it, it would probably be best to revert it.

What would be a good test to do? Should I try loading a dae from mixamo and check if the mesh is imported correctly?

content.raw:
To me it seems like all of the affected functions are only meant for internal use, but since they're public functions I guess we can't guarantee that no one else is depending on them.

With respect to changing function signatures, one of the big problems is that Koon Peng ran into is that these classes weren't designed to support multiple “skeletons” in an animation, but many complex animations \(e.g. humanoids\) are constructed with multiple “skeletons” in them. The function signatures changes were made to accommodate that. Maybe we can keep the old function signatures and have those functions operate on the assumption that there's only one “skeleton” \(or vertex group to match the language of the new API\).

In terms of which Gazebo to target, it’s really important for us to have these fixes for our Singapore work, which is already a complex ecosystem combining ROS1 Melodic, ROS2 Crystal, and Gazebo 9. If we can get this released in a Gazebo 9 minor release, that would be ideal for us and our project partners.
content.html:
To me it seems like all of the affected functions are only meant for internal use, but since they're public functions I guess we can't guarantee that no one else is depending on them.

With respect to changing function signatures, one of the big problems is that Koon Peng ran into is that these classes weren't designed to support multiple “skeletons” in an animation, but many complex animations (e.g. humanoids) are constructed with multiple “skeletons” in them. The function signatures changes were made to accommodate that. Maybe we can keep the old function signatures and have those functions operate on the assumption that there's only one “skeleton” (or vertex group to match the language of the new API).

In terms of which Gazebo to target, it’s really important for us to have these fixes for our Singapore work, which is already a complex ecosystem combining ROS1 Melodic, ROS2 Crystal, and Gazebo 9. If we can get this released in a Gazebo 9 minor release, that would be ideal for us and our project partners.

content.raw:
I have a couple questions:

* how important is it that this be included in gazebo9 vs. the default branch (gazebo11)?
* the ABI change is from the added protected data member, which in a comment may not be necessary
* there are several changed function signatures in the API; if the existing functions are bad and need to go away, then at a minimum they should be deprecated and new ones added in parallel. If they can both co-exist, then just add new ones without deprecating.

it would also be nice to have some kind of test if possible, but I understand if that is not trivial
content.html:
I have a couple questions:

  • how important is it that this be included in gazebo9 vs. the default branch (gazebo11)?
  • the ABI change is from the added protected data member, which in a comment may not be necessary
  • there are several changed function signatures in the API; if the existing functions are bad and need to go away, then at a minimum they should be deprecated and new ones added in parallel. If they can both co-exist, then just add new ones without deprecating.

it would also be nice to have some kind of test if possible, but I understand if that is not trivial

content.raw: This is looking great! I’ve left a few comments below, probably the most significant one being the concern about changing the ABI.
content.html: This is looking great! I’ve left a few comments below, probably the most significant one being the concern about changing the ABI.

content.raw: Exceptions are discouraged by our C\+\+ style guide, so I recommend using `if(frame.find(...) != frame.end())` instead.
content.html: Exceptions are discouraged by our C++ style guide, so I recommend using if(frame.find(...) != frame.end()) instead.

content.raw:
This might change the [ABI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application_binary_interface), depending on whether or not this class is considered part of the public API. If it’s part of the API, then we may need to see about using a different implementation. 

Is this part of the following bullet point?

> Allow Skeleton to store data of raw node weights with multiple vertices group. The raw node weights are overwritten when loading a new submesh, while not strictly required becauses submeshes are load sequentially, it is probably more "correct" to have the full node weights available.

If so, then we can just consider reverting to the old implementation if adding this member field impacts the ABI and doesn’t offer any functional difference to the end user.
content.html:
This might change the ABI, depending on whether or not this class is considered part of the public API. If it’s part of the API, then we may need to see about using a different implementation.

Is this part of the following bullet point?

Allow Skeleton to store data of raw node weights with multiple vertices group. The raw node weights are overwritten when loading a new submesh, while not strictly required becauses submeshes are load sequentially, it is probably more "correct" to have the full node weights available.

If so, then we can just consider reverting to the old implementation if adding this member field impacts the ABI and doesn’t offer any functional difference to the end user.

content.raw:
Using exceptions is discouraged in our C\+\+ style guidelines for various reasons.

I would recommend using the `.find()` function here instead.
content.html:
Using exceptions is discouraged in our C++ style guidelines for various reasons.

I would recommend using the .find() function here instead.

content.raw:
Have we done a test on this?

I know I told you that for when it comes to colors, `0.0` usually means totally transparent while `1.0` means totally opaque, but that was referring to the `alpha channel` in an RGBA color scheme. I’m not actually sure how the value would map for a material property that’s being called “transparency”. This may have already been fine the way it was.
content.html:
Have we done a test on this?

I know I told you that for when it comes to colors, 0.0 usually means totally transparent while 1.0 means totally opaque, but that was referring to the alpha channel in an RGBA color scheme. I’m not actually sure how the value would map for a material property that’s being called “transparency”. This may have already been fine the way it was.

content.raw: Style nitpick: Since this runs across two lines, I think our style guide rules say that it needs to be wrapped in `{ ... }` curly braces.
content.html: Style nitpick: Since this runs across two lines, I think our style guide rules say that it needs to be wrapped in { ... } curly braces.
